title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many wintering in Latin America and the Caribbean. These neotropical migratory birds offer valuable benefits to the environment, economy, recreation, and aesthetics. However, some populations are declining, jeopardizing their long-term survival in the wild. Neotropical migratory birds face habitat loss and degradation, threatening their long-term survival. Conservation efforts require international cooperation and increased coordination to strengthen initiatives. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, assist in their conservation through initiatives in the US, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources and foster international cooperation for these efforts. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act defines "Account" as the fund established for bird conservation. "Conservation" includes protecting bird populations, habitat management, research, and law enforcement. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act establishes an "Account" for bird conservation, which includes protecting bird populations, habitat management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach and education. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act establishes financial assistance for bird conservation efforts. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities including individuals, corporations, government agencies, and foreign entities. To be considered for financial assistance under this Act, project proposals must include the name of the project leader, a brief statement of project goals, qualifications of project staff, and an estimate of funds and time needed, including matching funds. The project must demonstrate how it will enhance the conservation of neotropical migratory bird species in the US, Latin America, or the Caribbean. It should also include mechanisms for local public participation, consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to local historic and cultural resources, and compliance with applicable laws. The project must promote sustainable, long-term programs to conserve neotropical migratory birds and provide necessary information for evaluation. Recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for project progress evaluation. The Federal share of project costs must be determined. Cost Sharing:
- Federal share: Not greater than 25% of project cost.
- Non-federal share:
  - Source: Cannot come from any Federal grant program.
  - Form of payment:
    - Projects in the United States: Must be paid in cash.
    - Projects in foreign countries: Can be paid in cash or in kind. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary is required to develop guidelines for project proposals, encourage submissions from wildlife management authorities, select proposals that meet requirements and address conservation needs, and implement the Act accordingly. The Secretary is required to develop guidelines for project proposals, encourage submissions from wildlife management authorities, select proposals that meet requirements and address conservation needs, and generally implement this Act in accordance with its purposes. SEC. 7. COOPERATION. In carrying out the Act, the Secretary will support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and conducting appropriate activities. The Secretary will coordinate activities and projects with existing efforts to enhance conservation of neotropical migratory bird species. An advisory group may be convened to assist in carrying out the Act, consisting of individuals from public and private organizations involved in bird conservation. The advisory group will hold open meetings with public participation opportunities. The advisory group will hold open meetings with public participation opportunities, providing a chance for interested persons to present statements on agenda items. The Secretary will give timely notice of each meeting and keep minutes available to the public. The group is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, detailing the results and effectiveness of the program under the Act, along with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a provision for the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations for conservation purposes without the need for further appropriation. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund allows for the use of donations and appropriations without the need for further appropriation. The Secretary can use amounts in the Account for administrative expenses and accept donations to carry out the Act. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2005 for projects outside the United States.
